questions.question_text:
Note: This question is part of series of questions that present the same scenario. Each question in the series contains a unique solution that might meet the stated goals. Some question sets might have more than one correct solution, while others might not have a correct solution.
After you answer a question in this section, you will NOT be able to return to it. As a result, these questions will not appear in the review screen.
A company backs up data to on-premises servers at their main facility. The company currently has 30 TB of archived data that infrequently used. The facility has download speeds of 100 Mbps and upload speeds of 20 Mbps.
You need to securely transfer all backups to Azure Blob Storage for long-term archival. All backup data must be sent within seven days.
Solution: Backup data to local disks and use the Azure Import/Export service to send backups to Azure Blob Storage.
Does this meet the goal?

You need to ensure that App1 can query a database on SQL1.
Which three actions should you perform in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You are designing a solution to secure a company's Azure resources. The environment hosts 10 teams. Each team manages a project and has a project manager, a virtual machine (VM) operator, developers, and contractors.
Project managers must be able to manage everything except access and authentication for users. VM operators must be able to manage VMs, but not the virtual network or storage account to which they are connected. Developers and contractors must be able to manage storage accounts.
You need to recommend roles for each member.
What should you recommend? To answer, drag the appropriate roles to the correct employee types. Each role may be used once, more than once, or not at all.
You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

comments.content: Yes, Given answers are correct.

discussion.content:
Queue-Single Consumer
Topics-Multiple Consumers
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/service-bus-messaging/service-bus-queues-topics-subscriptions
Correct
why is the second answer service bus topic and not event grid topic

comments.content: Event Grid is for event processing. App2 needs to be consumed by multiple customers, hence service bus topic.

When we are looking for processing millions of events with high throughput, velocity and near-real-time processing Azure Event Grid can opt-in comparison with Azure Service Bus Topic whereas Azure Service Bus Topics can be used for more fan-out transactional processing. and when it is to do with APP i guess Service bus topic pub- sub model is opt. in case it is ioT or big data scenario then serverless option like event grid will make sense ( according to me Ans is Correct)

discussion.content: And https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/service-bus-messaging/service-bus-messaging-overview

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You have an Azure subscription that contains an Azure Service Bus named Bus1.
Your company plans to deploy two Azure web apps named App1 and App2. The web app will create messages that have the following requirements:
✑ Each message created by App1 must be consumed by only a single consumer.
✑ Each message created by App2 will consumed by multiple consumers.
Which resource should you create for each web app? To answer, drag the appropriate resources to the correct web apps. Each resource may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

You have an Azure subscription that contains the resources shown in the following table.
//IMG//

Subnet1 is on VNET1. VM1 connects to Subnet1.
You plan to create a virtual network gateway on VNET1.
You need to prepare the environment for the planned virtual network gateway.
What are two ways to achieve this goal? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

comments.content: onlyfunmails is correct. Once subnet is deleted a new one can be created which takes less ips and then there will be room for a GW
you can perform the step C only when step B is done. and they are asking for first two steps. so C is correct but stands as third step. so the first two is A and E

C is preparation step (pre-requisite) for VNG.

A & C

Sorry, I don't sure about E is a correct solution.
Question said: Each answer presents a COMPLETE solution.

A: It's correct because we can add new address space to a subnet. => OK
B: It's correct too if we think that VM is not associate with subnet01 ("in table: address space - Not applicable"). If we think that it isn't associate, we can modify subnet if it don't any any VM associate (I checked). Then, we can modify 10.1.1.0/24 to a new subnet with less IPs, changing address space to 10.1.1.0/25. In this way, we have subnet1 from 10.1.1.0 to 10.1.1.127 ip address. Then we will have an address space from 10.1.1.128 to 10.1.1.255 free. So, we can create GatewaySubnet for example with 10.1.1.128/28 address space.
E: Deleted Subnet1. We can do this solution only if subnet1 don't have any VM associate, else we can't deleted. So, if there isn't a VM then is better solution B and modify subnet, because if we deleted subnet1 we can create a Gatewaysubnet but we already need subnet1 to attach the VM.
A, E are correct. Question says "Each correct answer presents a COMPLETE solution".
B. Modify the address space used by Subnet1 >>> not an option as it is being used by VM1. In case subnet is not used by any resource, address range can be changed.

discussion.content:
Answer is correct [ A, E ] , will explain : 

A. Modify the address space used by VNET1 >>> an option

B. Modify the address space used by Subnet1 >>> not an option as you can't modify subnet address after creating it, you can only delete the whole subnet.

C. Create a subnet named GatewaySubnet on VNET1 >>> this is an implementation step for the GW and the question asking for preparation steps, not implementation steps.

D. Create a local network gateway. >>> >> this is an implementation step for the GW and the question asking for preparation steps, not implementation steps

E. Delete Subnet1. >> an option ( as then you have free space to create the GatewaySubnet and also you can later create small subnet for the VMs )
A and C

Yes, A and C are correct. But C doesn't provide a complete solution but I didn't see any other applicable answers here.
B. Modify the address space used by Subnet1. - Once the Subnet1 is created, you can't modify the address space after that.
D. Create a local network gateway. - This step will be done usually after creating the GatewaySubnet in VNet1

"Failed to delete subnet 'default'. Error: Subnet default is in use by testwvm01672/ipconfig1 and cannot be deleted. In order to delete the subnet, delete all the resources within the subnet. See aka.ms/deletesubnet."

I did this in the lab
Set up a Vnet with the address space 10.1.1.0/24
Set up a Subnet with the address space 10.1.1.0/24

Now I changed the Address space of the Vnet1 to 10.1.0.0/16 
This updated the Vnet1 to 10.1.0.0/16 and the subnet still had 10.1.1.0/24
Next I created a Gatewaysubnet with 10.1.0.0/28

I have now prepared the environment to set up the Virtual Network Gateway.
So the answer is A & C

discussion.content:
Answer is A&C
A. Modify the address space used by VNET1.
C. Create a subnet named GatewaySubnet on VNET1.
A and C

A. Modify the address space used by VNET1.

- Even if we have resources connected to one of our subnets (VM1) we are able to resize it. 

B. Modify the address space used by Subnet1.

- This is not possible, as VM1 is connected to Subnet1 and we therefor can't change the address space anymore.

C. Create a subnet named GatewaySubnet on VNET1.

- This would be the first step when creating a VPN GW. 

D. Create a local network gateway.

- This would be the second preparation step. But we first need to create a GatewaySubnet. So this point can be ruled out IMHO. 

E. Delete Subnet1.

- We can't delete the subnet, as we have VM1 connected to it. So this can be ruled out as well. 

Conclusion: 

A. & C. are the correct answers (tested and verified in lab)

comments.content:
A and C is correct
1. You can modify the address spaces on VNETs to get more room for more subnets
2. To create a VPN gateway you need a special subnet called and named Gateway Subnet.
3. There is no need to delete the already provisioned subnet because now that you have modified the VNET you have more address spaces.

Read the question correctly

discussion.content:
Answer is A & C. Having a VM1 in subnet 1 you cannot delete the subnet.

A. Modify the address space used by VNET1.
C. Create a subnet named GatewaySubnet on VNET1.

The problem is that the subnet holds all the space in the vnet so a gateway can't be created. C and D are, therefore, both wrong.
A is certainly an option to open up space to create the gateway.
B and E are not: You can't delete or modify a subnet once a VM is attached to it. 
So A is the first step in creating the subnet. Once you've opened up space, step C is the next step. So it's the question that's wrong: It should say "What are the two steps to..." not "two ways"

The answer is A and C
A - Modify the address space user by VNET1 to 10.1.0.0/16
C - Create a subnet for the planned Gateway
Wrong answers
B - You can´t modify subnet because is in use
E - You can't delete subnet because is in use
D - Local network gateway is onpremises related
